messages.text: I am experiencing something very strange. Given a UDE, which I am fitting on some data ( using a med. size network ~ 200 parameters ). Using Forwarddiff, the Loss is falling as expected. Switching to InterpolatingAdjoint, the loss is increasing ( for any number of iterations ). Only tweaking the learning rate of ADAM to be negativ leads to a decreasing loss. Is anyone else having these problems?

messages.text: <@U69BL50BF> say, I was watching you two videos from the Fall course on PINNs and the DiffEqFlux tutorials. It seems like all the models use basic feedforward networks instead of RNNs. I was just wondering why not use RNNs, since the ODE model outputs and data are sequential time-series?

elements.text: say, I was watching you two videos from the Fall course on PINNs and the DiffEqFlux tutorials. It seems like all the models use basic feedforward networks instead of RNNs. I was just wondering why not use RNNs, since the ODE model outputs and data are sequential time-series?

messages.text: because then you wouldn't have explicit continuous time.

elements.text: because then you wouldn't have explicit continuous time.

messages.text: there is a DeepGalerkinMethod which uses LSTMs in time.

elements.text: there is a DeepGalerkinMethod which uses LSTMs in time.

messages.text: Oh interesting. So then the standard feedforward network is a better "representation" for continuous time than using an RNN. I am not sure if "representation" is the right word. But in my simple mind, I think of a feedforward network as having no representation of time or sequence--though some folks have modelled time series using feed forward networks. Do you know of any reference for something like this? I want to understand how this argument is actually developed. Like is there a paper on the DeepGalerkinMethod that I should search for.

elements.text: Oh interesting. So then the standard feedforward network is a better "representation" for continuous time than using an RNN. I am not sure if "representation" is the right word. But in my simple mind, I think of a feedforward network as having no representation of time or sequence--though some folks have modelled time series using feed forward networks. Do you know of any reference for something like this? I want to understand how this argument is actually developed. Like is there a paper on the DeepGalerkinMethod that I should search for.

messages.text: Like there seems to be an article by Sirignano and Spiliopoulos (2018). Is that the one to look at.

elements.text: Like there seems to be an article by Sirignano and Spiliopoulos (2018). Is that the one to look at.

messages.text: the one way to make it actually well-defined as a model is to make it a fixed time step integrator, in which case you can't have step rejections and so there's actually a well-defined value at a given time point.

elements.text: the one way to make it actually well-defined as a model is to make it a fixed time step integrator, in which case you can't have step rejections and so there's actually a well-defined value at a given time point.

messages.text:
even tho its not correct usage, why stackoverflow? trace in reply
```using ModelingToolkit, OrdinaryDiffEq
@parameters t, r
@variables x(t)
D = Differential(t)
eq = D(x) ~ 1 + r*x + x^2 
one = ODESystem([eq], name=:one)
EnsembleProblem(one, -1:0.01:1)```

elements.text: even tho its not correct usage, why stackoverflow? trace in reply

EnsembleProblem(one, -1:0.01:1)

messages.text: notice julia (and many company libraries) doesn't run natively on M1 yet so you're running with Rosetta. It doesn't become warm because max TDP of that M1 chip is just low, which is why it can be a fan-less in the first place. You probably had a really old laptop before this.

messages.text:
Iâ€™m trying to optimize initial conditions for a 2nd order ODE:
```pÌ„â‚“â‚“(pÌ„â‚“, pÌ„, Î¸, x) = -k^2 * pÌ„

function loss(Î¸)
  ð’« = SecondOrderODEProblem{false}(pÌ„â‚“â‚“, Î¸[1], Î¸[2], (0.5f0, 1.0f0))
  sol = solve(ð’«, Tsit5(); saveat=train_x)
  mean(abs2, [abs(u[2])  for u âˆˆ sol.u] .- train_y)
end

res = DiffEqFlux.sciml_train(loss, [1.0f0, 0.0f0], ADAM(0.1); maxiters=100)```
The `loss()` function can be evaluated manually and it works just fine, but when I run it using `sciml_train()`, I get a:
```ERROR: MethodError: no method matching similar(::Float32, ::Type{Float32})```
which seems to be occurring during the pullback evaluation while accessing `sol.u` which is a `Vector{ArrayPartition{Float32, Tuple{Float32, Float32}}}`. In the forward pass, there is no problem, however. Any advise would be appreciated.

elements.text: Iâ€™m trying to optimize initial conditions for a 2nd order ODE:

pÌ„â‚“â‚“(pÌ„â‚“, pÌ„, Î¸, x) = -k^2 * pÌ„

function loss(Î¸)
  ð’« = SecondOrderODEProblem{false}(pÌ„â‚“â‚“, Î¸[1], Î¸[2], (0.5f0, 1.0f0))
  sol = solve(ð’«, Tsit5(); saveat=train_x)
  mean(abs2, [abs(u[2])  for u âˆˆ sol.u] .- train_y)
end

res = DiffEqFlux.sciml_train(loss, [1.0f0, 0.0f0], ADAM(0.1); maxiters=100)
The
loss()
function can be evaluated manually and it works just fine, but when I run it using
sciml_train()
, I get a:
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching similar(::Float32, ::Type{Float32})
which seems to be occurring during the pullback evaluation while accessing
sol.u
which is a
Vector{ArrayPartition{Float32, Tuple{Float32, Float32}}}
. In the forward pass, there is no problem, however. Any advise would be appreciated.

messages.text: I am trying to do PDE constrained optimization and I use the method of lines to solve the system. I think I have optimized this step fairly well (running the derivative function only has 17 memory allocations of around 700 bytes). Right now, I have around 10 parameters and the system is spatially one-dimensional with 1000 discrete points (I am going to move to two dimensions once I get this working). The loss function is the L2 norm at 5 different time points. However, the optimization process is very slow. Any advice for the best optimization algorithms and sensitivity methods to use for problems of this sort? Thanks.

elements.text: I am trying to do PDE constrained optimization and I use the method of lines to solve the system. I think I have optimized this step fairly well (running the derivative function only has 17 memory allocations of around 700 bytes). Right now, I have around 10 parameters and the system is spatially one-dimensional with 1000 discrete points (I am going to move to two dimensions once I get this working). The loss function is the L2 norm at 5 different time points. However, the optimization process is very slow. Any advice for the best optimization algorithms and sensitivity methods to use for problems of this sort? Thanks.

messages.text:
Are there any tips and tricks to speed up `ModelingToolkit.sparsejacobian`? So far I just made a state vector using `@variables`, ran it through my dynamics, and called `ModelingToolkit.sparsejacobian(du, u; simplify=true)`. I realize simplification may contribute nontrivially to the time.

My problem is somewhat complex and the statedim is 2130, but the jacobian should be pretty sparse. I don't have a strict number on a sparsity ratio (at least until this would finish running :smile:). I suppose I could try to estimate it with `ForwardDiff` and some random inputs.

elements.text: Are there any tips and tricks to speed up
ModelingToolkit.sparsejacobian
? So far I just made a state vector using
@variables
, ran it through my dynamics, and called
ModelingToolkit.sparsejacobian(du, u; simplify=true)

. I realize simplification may contribute nontrivially to the time.

My problem is somewhat complex and the statedim is 2130, but the jacobian should be pretty sparse. I don't have a strict number on a sparsity ratio (at least until this would finish running
). I suppose I could try to estimate it with
ForwardDiff
and some random inputs.

messages.text: not any more that I know of. You may want to cache the sparsity pattern instead of run it every time if it's very large.

elements.text: not any more that I know of. You may want to cache the sparsity pattern instead of run it every time if it's very large.
